title: Willem Dafoe reflects on the 'crazy' preparations required for his role in iconic 1986 film Platoon
text:
He's received Academy Award nominations at the last two Oscars.

But Willem Dafoe has reflected on the role that earned him his first nod -Sergeant Elias Gordon in 1986's Platoon- in the latest episode of Inside The Actors Studio, set to air this Sunday.

'It was crazy. You could never do this now,' he told interviewer Pedro Pascal of his preparation for Oliver Stone's iconic war film.

Looking back: Willem Dafoe has reflected on the role that earned him his first nod -Sergeant Elias Gordon in 1986's Platoon- in the latest episode of Inside The Actors Studio, set to air this Sunday

'It was very important that we learned how to do soldier things,' began the 64-year-old Spider-Man star.

'[The film's producers] took us, put us in a bus, drove out in the middle of the jungle, had us get out of the bus, and the bus drove away.'

'And I remember [co-star] Kevin Dillon saying, "Oh man, I gotta call my agent!" and they were like, "You know what, good luck."'

Crazy times: 'It was crazy. You could never do this now,' he told interviewer Pedro Pascal of his preparation for Oliver Stone's iconic war film

Getting into character: 'It was very important that we learned how to do soldier things,' began the 64-year-old Spider-Man star. Seen here on set in 1986

Along with Dillon (Entourage), the all star cast for the 1987 Best Picture winner included Tom Berenger, Charlie Sheen, Johnny Depp and Forest Whitaker among others.

Recently, Dafoe's career has been resurgent, with the actor garnering Oscar nominations for his roles in The Florida Project in 2018 and At Eternity's Gate in 2019.

He is already earning rave reviews for his role alongside Robert Pattinson in their thriller The Lighthouse, which is currently in theaters.

The film is about two lighthouse keepers who try to maintain their sanity while living on a remote and mysterious New England island in the 1890s.

New episodes of Inside the Actors Studio air each Sunday at 10:00 p.m. ET on Ovation TV.
